Project Description  The  Project  will  construct  and  rehabilitate  206  kilometers  of 
transmission network, and rehabilitate the associated substations 
and distribution systems in 11 rural towns and adjacent rural areas 
in the northern, eastern, and southern provinces. The Project will 
connect 90,700 new consumers, most of whom are poor, to the 
grid and, in addition, will allocate 18,000 electricity connection kits, 
with affordable and flexible payment options.  
 
Rationale  Most of Afghanistan’s 28 million people—mostly rural poor—have 
no access to reliable, modern forms of energy such as electricity, 
gas, and liquid fuels. The national electrification ratio is about 9%. 
As the power sector’s poor state severely constrains economic 
growth, the Government puts priority on developing the sector. 
  Afghanistan’s  power  generation,  transmission,  and  distribution 
systems have been severely damaged by years of conflict. There 
is no national transmission grid, and the overall condition of lines is 
very  poor.  The  Northern  Transmission  Link,  which  is  being 
rehabilitated, serves the major northern cities and Kabul and is the 
backbone  of  the  transmission  system.  Because  of  the  lack  of 
generation capacity, power has to be imported in the near term 
from neighboring countries, which are rich in gas. In the long term, 
when Afghanistan’s hydropower potential is realized, power could 
be exported to neighboring countries. The transmission system 
needs to be rehabilitated and reinforced to improve reliability and 
reduce system losses. 
 
  Distribution  systems  are  stretched  beyond  their  technical  and 
economic  lives  because  of  inadequate  investment  and  lack  of 
maintenance.  The  substations  and  low-voltage  distribution 
networks are either destroyed or overloaded. A large number of 
unauthorized  consumers  are  overloading  the  system,  thus 
reducing supply voltage and increasing technical losses.

A 2005 International Monetary Fund (IMF) debt sustainability study 
suggests that Afghanistan will need to rely primarily on grants and, 
in a limited way, on borrowings. It highlights the importance of a 
high grant element for loans.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan, and (ii) a proposed grant, both to  the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan for the  Power 
Transmission and Distribution Project. The report also describes proposed technical assistance 
(TA) for capacity building of the Ministry of Energy and Water (MEW), and if the Board approves 
the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the 
TA. The Design and Monitoring Framework is in Appendix 1. 
  
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
2.  Most of Afghanistan’s nearly 28 million people are rural poor, with no access to reliable, 
modern forms of energy such as electricity, gas, and liquid fuels.  As the power sector’s poor 
state severely constrains economic growth, the Government puts priority on developing the 
sector. Afghanistan’s per capita power consumption is among the lowest in the world (21 
kilowatt  hours  [kWh]  per  year),  and  only  about  234,000  customers  (less  than  10%1)  are 
connected to the isolated public grid, of which about 30% is in Kabul. There is no national power 
grid, and most rural areas are virtually unserved. Reliable power service is critical to economic 
growth, social equity, and political unity. 
 
3.  The  power  sector  needs  immediate  investment  in  generation,  transmission,  and 
distribution. Four isolated power systems—centered around Kandahar in the south, Kabul in the 
center, Herat in the west, and Mazar-e-Sharif in the north—form the main power infrastructure 
as most rural town centers are remote, isolated, and separated by mountains. The power 
distribution infrastructure has been destroyed and needs major rehabilitation. Although the total 
installed generation capacity is 453 megawatt (MW), only 250 MW is generated, and most 
generating units require overhaul or replacement. Appendix 2 analyzes the power sector in 
detail. 
 
4.  Afghanistan has  large hydropower potential (more than 20,000 MW) that could be 
exported in the long term to lessen reliance on expensive gas-based generation in neighboring 
countries. In the interim, however, Afghanistan has to rely on imported power to meet growing 
power demand. Based on annual power purchase agreements, it imports about 76 gigawatt-
hours  (GWh)  from  Uzbekistan2  to  meet  demand  in  Balkh  and  Hairatan,  18.2  GWh  from 
Turkmenistan to meet demand in Herat, and 12.3 GWh from Tajikistan to meet demand in 
Kunduz and other northern provinces. 
 
5.  A centralized transmission grid covering the whole country (based on load forecast) is 
not economically feasible as the distance between load centers greatly raises the cost of 
transmission and energy losses.  Two other transmission projects—Hairatan to Pul-e-Khumri 
(funded by ADB) and Pul-e-Khumri to Kabul (funding under consideration by the US Agency for 
International Development [USAID] and the Government of India) are creating the backbone of 
the transmission network, enabling the import of electricity to Kabul. The isolated distribution 
systems  are  stretched  beyond  their  technical  and  economic  lives  because  of  inadequate

weakest link in the economy, and investments and management reform are urgently needed to

6.  Technical losses due to overloading of transmission and distribution equipment, and 
substandard overhead conductors and underground cable joints are estimated to be about 20–

Overall load shedding (cutting off the power on certain lines when demand becomes greater 
than supply), unreliable supply, and high system losses have paralyzed the power sector.  
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
1.  Institutional Framework 
 
7.  In December 2004, the newly elected Government created the Ministry of Energy and 
Water (MEW) by merging the responsibilities of the Ministry of Water and Power and some 
responsibilities  of  the  Ministry  of  Mines  and  Industry.  MEW  is  responsible  for  power, gas, 
petroleum, and water resources. In the power sector, MEW controls the operation of five state-
owned  enterprises:  (i)  Afghanistan  Electricity  Authority  (DABM)—power  generation, 
transmission, and distribution; 5,421 employees; (ii) Spinghar Construction Unit—civil works for 
the power sector; 385 employees; (iii) Power Construction Unit—erection of transmission and 
distribution  lines  and  substations;  420  employees;  (iv)  Water  and  Power  Engineering 
Consultancy  Authority—design  and  field  survey  of  new  generation,  transmission,  and 
distribution; 182 employees; and (v) New and Renewable Energy Research and Development 
Centre—development of renewable energy; 149 employees. Although the Enterprise Act of 
1980 sets out their responsibilities, in practice these enterprises are closely controlled by MEW. 
DABM—the vertically integrated power utility—manages about 80% of the country’s electricity 
production, while the ministries of mines and industry and of light industry share management of 
the remaining 20%. The Government owns all these enterprises, which directly report to MEW. 
 
8.  The massive brain drain and collapse of the educational system have left Afghanistan 
with limited local analytical and management capabilities. Limited absorptive capacity is a major 
bottleneck for effective donor assistance. Business, technical, and operational skills must be 
developed immediately to rebuild the power sector. External consultants have carried out 
procurement, project management, and planning, on an interim basis, under different ADB 
programs to develop institutions’ capacity to assume responsibility for these functions and to 
improve the country’s capacity to absorb assistance. DABM lacks the economic and operational 
resources to provide basic electricity supply. Most DABM staff lack the technical skills to operate 
the power system. DABM’s financial situation is unsustainable mainly because of inadequate 
generation to meet demand, low tariffs, large losses, and poor collection. The Government 
recently received World Bank assistance3 to commercialize DABM (i.e., to restructure and 
incorporate it, to computerize financial management, and to apply a recommended multiyear 
tariff path); and to wage a major public relations campaign to communicate the Government’s 
vision, strategy, and reform program to all stakeholders. This initiative complements ADB’s 
work.

  2.  Power Shortage in Kabul 
 
9.  Kabul, with 3 million people, has no permanent power source—only three hydropower 
stations and a diesel-fueled gas turbine (44 MW). The total effective generation capacity is 145 
MW, and the maximum peak demand is about 140 MW, excluding the 50 MW load that is 
usually shed during peak periods. A large part of electricity supply is generated by diesel and 
funded by USAID. According to the Government’s master plan, maximum demand in Kabul will 
reach about 320 MW by 2020, and new hydropower or gas-based thermal power production can 
be available only after 2010. Under the master plan, the increase of power supply to Kabul in 
the short term has to be based on a combination of the following: (i) new, small diesel plants; (ii) 
extension of the North West Thermal Power Station with a combined cycle unit; (iii) restoring of 
original generating capacity of existing hydropower plants; (iv) use of natural gas resources near 
Sheberghan;  and  (v)  import  of  power  from  neighboring  countries  in  the  north  over  new 
transmission lines to Kabul. 
 
10.  The Government plans to import about 150 MW from Uzbekistan to meet demand in 
Kabul via Khulm and Pul-i-Khumri. The line from Amu (in Uzbekistan) to Kabul is about 500 
kilometers (km): ADB is financing4 the stretch from Termez to Khulm and construction of two 
single  circuit  lines  from  Khulm  to  Pul-i-Khumri  (the  northern  link).  The  Government  has 
requested USAID to finance the construction of the transmission line from Pul-i-Khumri to Kabul.  
 
3.  Limited Rural Electrification 
11.  Rural electrification is a long-term prospect, and access to the grid for all is not a viable 
alternative. Most people live in rural areas and lead a very basic life. Their access to electricity 
is limited, almost nonexistent, worsening already poor education and health conditions. No 
major  small-scale  livelihood  program  has  been  developed  in  rural  areas.  Per  capita 
consumption of electricity is 21 kWh per month (one 100-watt light bulb consumes 1 kWh in 10 
hours). Rural electrification—with emphasis on renewable energy—may be the only way to 
recover lost economic opportunities. The Government is undertaking a comprehensive survey in 
renewable energy resources with support from ADB.5 The TA will establish the conditions 
(including a pilot project covering 10 remote villages) for using solar power in areas with no 
access to grid power.  
 
4.  Private Sector Participation 
12.  The power sector needs large amounts of investment in generation, transmission, and 
distribution. The Government has relied on aid finance to meet its capital expenditure, and 
operation and maintenance (O&M) costs are sometimes externally financed as power supply 
operation is unable to recover full operation cost, a situation worsened by growing security and 
safety concerns. The Government’s dependency on aid financing is likely to continue in the 
short to medium term, as the overall investment climate is not favorable to private or other

5.  Financial Sustainability 
13.  Financial sustainability needs infrastructure (generation, transmission, and distribution); 
effective  institutions  to  manage  the  business;  and  appropriate  tariff,  billing,  and  revenue 
collection. Afghanistan is challenged on all fronts. This situation and medium-term prospects are 
summarized in Appendix 2, Table A2.2. Although the average tariff for electricity is higher than 
in neighboring countries, tariffs6 only recover on average about 50% of cost. Unlike many 
developing countries, Afghanistan has location-specific tariffs rather than a uniform national 
tariff.  This  average  domestic  tariff  varies  widely  depending  on  the  source  of  power: 
hydropower—Kabul  and  Kandahar  (2.0  cents  per  kWh);  and  imported  energy  and  diesel 
generation—Mazar-e-Sharif (5.2), Kunduz (5.9), and Herat (9.1). The Government is committed 
to full cost recovery of hydro-based electricity and to the phased increase of electricity tariffs 
toward cost recovery in the medium term.  
 
14.  Nontechnical  loss  (estimated  at  15–20%) will have to be minimized and collection 
efficiency (60-70%) improved. Most of the uncollected revenues—AF1,300 million7 (about $30 
million) as of the end of October 2004—is mostly owed by public sector customers (e.g., the 
Government, military, and police). The Government has to ensure budget appropriation for 
unpaid customers in the Government sector and to issue policy guidelines on disconnection, 
and anti-theft measures.  
 
6.  Government’s Policies and Plans 
15.  The Government’s goal is to make energy more available at least-cost and in an 
environmentally friendly manner. In February 2004, the Government formulated an electricity 
sector policy and a power sector road map (Appendix 2). The main elements of the policy are 
sector  restructuring,  unbundling,  establishment  of  a  regulatory  framework,  and 
commercialization. The policy plans to supply the entire country  with reliable power and to 
create  730,000  more  connections  by  2010.  The  Government  aims  to  make  power  more 
available in the main regions by (i) investing in system rehabilitation; (ii) increasing supply, in 
part  by  importing  power;  and  (iii)  expanding  generation,  transmission,  and  distribution 
infrastructure.  
 
16.  The Government’s reform plan is to corporatize DABM and appoint a new board of 
directors. Four vertically integrated business units will be established, reflecting the current and 
medium-term regional grid structures: (i) Breshna East (covering Ghazni, Kabul, Khost , Logar, 
Nangarhar, and Pak Tia provinces); (ii) Breshna North (Baghlan,  Balkh,  Faryab,  Jowzjan,

provinces); and (iv) Breshna West (covering Baghdis, Faryab and Herat provinces). An off-grid

17.  In part, the Government’s policy follows the global trend of unbundling of the power 
sector, creation of an independent regulator, and separation of policy and operation. While an 
efficient energy sector is the paramount objective, care must be taken before implementing 
these strategies. The electricity system is small and the incremental benefit of unbundling must 
outweigh the cost of unbundling in the long run. Afghanistan may not have the management and 
technical  staff  to  efficiently  operate  three  or  more  independent  companies  after  sector 
unbundling. ADB will continue its policy dialogue with the Government together with other 
external  funding  agencies  on  the  practical  options  for  restructuring  and  unbundling  in 
accordance with economies of scale. 
 
7.  Lessons Learned  
18.  The key lessons learned from ADB operations since 2002 are the following: (i) the 
strategic focus has to be linked to the Government’s strategies and priorities, (ii) capacity 
building should continue to be emphasized, and (iii) coordination with development partners 
must be done properly. These lessons are included in the design of the Project, which covers (i) 
increased access to reliable power, a key Government priority; (ii) a separate TA for capacity 
building; (iii) active coordination through project implementation and support unit (PISU) and 
steering  committee;  and  (iv)  project  components  that  development  partners  agree  are 
immediate priorities.

9.  ADB’s Sector Strategy  
22.  ADB  has  taken  a  three-pronged  approach  to  support  reconstruction  and  poverty 
reduction: building capacity, establishing appropriate policy and institutional framework, and 
rehabilitating essential infrastructure.9 ADB’s strategy focuses on (i) maximizing the use of 
existing infrastructure by rehabilitating power substations, power transmission, and generation 
projects; (ii) improving the quality, reliability, and promotion of energy efficiency; (iii) managing 
security issues by coordinating closely with all stakeholders; (iv) establishing policies and 
institutions to improve importation of energy; (v) using renewable energy where possible; (vi) 
developing a consistent policy in regulation, environment, tariff, and energy efficiency; (vi) 
building capacity across the sector and promoting private-public sector partnerships in projects; 
and (vii) fast-tracking implementation where possible. 
 
23.  The Project, with its emphasis on rehabilitation of power infrastructure, facilitation of 
energy imports, promotion of energy efficiency (by using efficient lighting in connection kits), and 
support for capacity building, is consistent with ADB’s country operational strategy. ADB will 
work with the Government to encourage private companies to invest in generation in Kabul and 
provincial cities, and small private distribution networks to operate in isolated rural communities. 
Establishment of regulation by contract is necessary for private sector participation.

b.  Private Sector Participation 
26.  The  energy  sector  is  dominated  by  public  sector  monopolies.  The  Government is 
developing12 a framework to encourage private sector participation, particularly for base load 
power generation in large cities. As establishing a credible and capable independent regulator 
takes time (at least 5–7 years), in the interim, ADB will help the Government create a simple 
form of regulation by contract for power generation and distribution, and exemptions from 
licensing  requirements  for  small  captive  generation  and  embedded  distribution,  where 
applicable. Regulation by contract will commit the Government (and the regulatory commission 
that it will create) to implement a pre-specified tariff-setting system (with a reasonably high 
degree of certainty as to the company’s future revenues over several years), whereas the 
private company will agree to provide power distribution or  generation service of agreed-on 
quality to specified customers over a defined period.  
 
27.  Regulation by contract will (i) protect consumers from monopoly prices and poor service 
quality;  and  (ii)  attract  investors,  by  reducing  regulatory  risk,  who  will  invest  in  providing 
affordable  service.  However,  large  private  investors  in  the  main  cities  are  likely  to  be 
discouraged by perceived security and political risks, and only local small private investors in 
remote rural distribution and generation may benefit from simple regulation, as they are likely to 
be less sensitive to such risks.

F.  Asian Development Fund (ADF) IX Grant Financing 
35.  Under the ADF IX resolution13 donors agreed that ADF grants could be used to assist 
poor countries make the transition from post-conflict to peace and stability. Afghanistan was 
identified as one of the poorest post-conflict countries and eligible for ADF grants14. Prolonged 
conflict has endangered the poor, destroyed their economic opportunities, damaged water and 
electricity infrastructure, and disrupted delivery of basic services to the neediest. Access to a 
reliable  power  source  is  a  prerequisite  for  sustained  economic  growth,  and  grants  can 
accelerate such growth. The Project will increase access to power by rehabilitating distribution 
systems and providing electrification kits. 
 
36.  Afghanistan has made significant progress since the ouster of the Taliban regime. The 
Government has implemented a wide range of structural reforms and adhered to almost all 
quantitative indicators and structural benchmarks under the Staff-Monitored Program, led by the 
International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF).  Notwithstanding  these  achievements  and  double-digit 
economic growth over the last 2 years, the economic and fiscal situation continues to be 
extremely fragile. Security, economic, social, and administrative challenges are formidable. The 
country continues to need external development finance that does not fiscally burden the 
nascent administration. 
 
37.  The high growth rates since the end of the conflict have been fuelled primarily by 
external funding agency supported relief and construction activities as well as by the temporary 
end to the drought. However, to achieve growth targets over the medium term and to gradually 
replace  opium  production,  the  Government  must  aim  for  broad-based  and  sustainable 
development and identify new drivers of growth. Investment in the power sector is a prerequisite 
for sustained economic growth, and grants will greatly help accelerate this transition. Appendix 
4 describes the justification for the grant, and the debt sustainability issues in detail.  The 
Government will make the grant available to DABM under the subsidiary financing agreement 
with  conditions  including  DABM  perform  the  project,  and  write-down  outstanding  debt  of 
government departments in amounts equal to or less than disbursements of the grant.

acceptable manner in accordance with the Environmental Management and Monitoring Plan

b.  Social and Poverty Aspects 
 
56.  The project design included a social and poverty assessment  of 21 districts in four 
regions—north (Sarepul, Puli-e-Khumri-Kunduz, Shekhanbandar-Imam Sahib); east (Butkak, 
Surobi-Jalalabad-Mihtarlam);  and  southeast  (Muhammad  Agha-Gardez-Ghazni-Khost).  The 
survey team, including MEW staff members, surveyed over 1,100 households across the project

regions and conducted town meetings in nine project towns. The social and poverty survey 
showed  that  the  communities  prioritized  their  development  needs:  potable  drinking  water, 
electricity,  educational  facilities,  and  health facilities. All respondents said electricity would 
improve children’s learning opportunities as it would replace kerosene for lighting. Almost all 
respondents said electricity would improve livelihoods (98.3%) and health (95.0%). Women are 
expected to be the main beneficiaries of additional lighting and/or motive power for home-based 
income-generating  activities  and  improved  indoor  air  quality.  The  survey  established  that 
although the main use of electricity was for household lighting, people were willing to invest in 
other appliances to improve living conditions and livelihoods. The poverty and social analyses 
are in Appendix 12.  
 
57.  Alternative  sources  for  lighting  include  kerosene  or  diesel  lamps,  small  diesel 
generators, and battery-operated lights, and cost significantly more than grid electricity. It was 
clear that even the poorest could afford grid-connected electricity more than alternative forms. 
Electricity will be new to many project beneficiaries, and a safety awareness campaign is 
included  in  the  terms  of  reference  of  the  implementation  consultants  (Appendix  9).  The 
campaign will be conducted via schools, printed materials, community meetings, and the radio. 
Safety information will be included in the connection kits and during local consultation meetings.

benefit equally from the Project. Contractors will be required to ensure equal payment for equal 
work. MEW’s capacity to implement the social safeguards (resettlement action plan and social

appointed as a social safeguard supervisor, to oversee the implementation safeguard plans, 
and will receive on-the-job training and assistance from the project implementation consultants.

V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Economic and Financial Assessment 
1.  Economic Analysis 
64.  Investments to rehabilitate and upgrade the utilities’ infrastructure or to expand supplies 
will greatly improve the extent and quality of service. In particular, investments to upgrade the 
asset base are expected to increase economic and financial returns. Better quality of supply and 
greater access to electricity are expected to reduce the cost of energy for households and to 
support  productive  activities  (industrial,  commercial,  etc.),  and  thereby  help  meet  the 
Government’s growth and poverty reduction objectives. 
 
65.  The  Project’s  economic  analysis  is  based  on  incremental  cost-and-benefit  streams 
associated with each component, whose economic performance is evaluated by comparing 
with- and without-project scenarios. Revenue is based on incremental electricity sales to the 
additional  customers  to  be  connected  and  financed  under  the  Project.  The  value  of  the 
increased sales is a measure of project benefits. The value of electricity is derived from the cost 
of  alternate  energy  sources  that  consumers  use.  Incremental  benefit  is  calculated  using 
customers’ willingness to pay. The overall economic internal rate of return (EIRR) is about 33% 
(Appendix 15, Table 15.1). The sensitivity of economic performance to changes in key variables 
has been tested. In general, EIRRs are not sensitive to the variables tested, even for the 
multiple downside scenarios. 
 
2.  Financial Analysis 
66.  For financial evaluation, cost streams reflect incremental costs in delivering the benefits 
identified. Financial costs comprise costs of capital, incremental energy, O&M, administration 
(particularly  additional  billing),  and  taxation.  Capital  costs  include  physical  contingencies. 
Incremental energy costs are accrued to additional generation and power purchase to be 
supplied to the project area. DABM’s sources of generation are mostly hydro,  but relatively 
inexpensive power imports will be available to the project area through the transmission lines to 
be extended by the Project. O&M costs for transmission and distribution systems are estimated 
to be 1.0% and 1.5% of required capital costs.  
 
67.  The financial internal rate of return (FIRR) is calculated on the basis of the Project’s 
incremental cost-and-benefit streams. The FIRR after tax is 11.8%, which is higher than the 
weighted average cost of capital. The FIRR was tested for sensitivity to changes in key 
variables. The results are summarized in Appendix 16, Table A.16, indicating that the overall 
Project is financially feasible. The FIRRs are not sensitive to variables tested, even for multiple 
downside (combined) scenarios.  
 
B.  Social and Poverty Reduction Benefits 
68.  A  benefit  distribution  analysis  conducted  as  part  of  the  social  and  poverty  survey 
estimated the number of beneficiaries for each town by extrapolating the number of poor for 
each town, each town’s electrification rates, and customers’ willingness to pay for electricity. 
The results indicate that the Project would directly benefit 1.2 million poor people, or 95,500 
households—about 80% of the target population of 1.5 million.

17 
69.  Benefits to the poor will be increased economic opportunities and improved health. 
Appendix 12 shows the calculation for proportion of poor beneficiaries. A distribution analysis of 
project  benefits  was  carried  out  for  the  affected  groups  identified  as  producers  (DABM), 
unskilled labor (10% of the project cost), the Government, and electricity consumers (90% poor, 
living below $1 per day). The analysis quantified the incidence of poverty in the project areas by 
using poverty profiles of different proposed routes, and the result was included in the economic 
viability of that route. The poverty impact ratios (PIRs) for the subprojects were computed at 
25%  to  over  100%.  PIRs  are  all  high  primarily  because  the  overwhelming  proportion  of 
electricity  consumers  in  the  target  area are poor, and electricity consumers are the main 
beneficiaries. PIRs greater than 100% indicate that at least one project-affected group (DABM in 
all cases) faces financial loss in providing positive economic value to consumers. 
 
C.  Risks 
 
70.  The overall political and security situation remains volatile and uncertain. Security—
mobility  restriction  to  and  within  Afghanistan,  and  personal  safety—could  delay  project 
implementation. An interministerial committee will be established to continue guidance in all 
aspects of security.  
 
71.  Weak implementation capacity on the part of the government could lead to delay in 
implementation. In addition weak governance structures within government raises the specter of 
corruption as a risk. Also weak implementation capacity in accounting and finances increases 
these risks. The risk of delay because of inadequate implementation capacity will be mitigated 
by  training  staff  of  MEW  (in  project  management,  planning)  and  DABM  (in  design, 
implementation, and operation and maintenance).  Institutional reform required to improve the 
sector’s sustainability and operation will be pursued under the Government’s Priority Reform 
and Restructuring program in cooperation with all external funding agencies. 
 
72.  Adequate investment in generation and transmission will be ensured by coordination 
with other donor agencies and the Government in a way consistent with the power sector 
master plan.  
 
73.  A further risk is that the allocation of electrification kits may be influenced by corruption. 
The Project protects against this risk by requiring a transparent procedure to establish objective 
allocation criteria for the kits. It also establishes a grievance, complaints and dispute resolution 
mechanism for customers receiving kits.

POWER SECTOR ANALYSIS AND SECTOR ROADMAP 
 
A.  Power Sector 
1.  The power sector is one of the least developed sectors in Afghanistan, and it is the key 
bottleneck for economic development. Afghanistan is well endowed with hydropower, natural 
gas, and coal. Some estimates put hydropower potential at 25,000 megawatts (MW), of which 
5,000 MW are inside Afghanistan and the rest on the border of Amu Darya.  Hydropower the 
key sources (about 75% of total) of power supply in Afghanistan: the main dams are Kajakai in 
Helmand  Province  near  Kandahar,  Mahipar  and  Breshna-Kot  in  Nangarhar  Province  near 
Jalalabad, and Dahla in Kandahar Province. Kabul is fed by three hydroelectric power stations, 
with a combined output of 80 MW (nameplate rating of 188 MW).  
 
2.  The total generation capacity has declined from about 456 MW in 1990s to about 250 
MW. Only about 6–9% of the population has access to power, of whom approximately 30% are 
in Kabul. The other provinces have even less access, with rural areas being virtually unserved. 
Before the conflict in 1980, power transmission lines comprised about 140 circuit-kilometers and 
about 1,080 circuit-kilometers of 220 kilovolt (kV) and 110 kV transmission lines, respectively. 
Many were destroyed during the war and only some 110 kV are now operating. The damaged 
220 kV lines have been downgraded to operate at 110 kV while some damaged 110 kV lines 
now operate at 35 kV.  
 
B.  Demand Scenarios 
3.  Energy demand forecasts have been made by the ongoing studies on the power sector 
master plan (up to 2020) and the gas development master plan (up to 2025). The power 
demand forecast is based on adjusted actual energy sales of 2002. Adjusted demand includes 
the suppressed demand, which is around 75% of the energy supplied. In the basic forecast, 
energy demand is assumed to reach 3,861 GWh in 2020, giving an average annual growth rate 
of 6.3%. In the high forecast, energy demand is assumed to reach 5,640 GWh in 2020, or 46% 
higher than the basic forecast, implying an average growth rate of 8.2%.  
 
4.  The present peak load is assumed around 215 MW for all of Afghanistan. Adding a 
suppressed demand assumed to be 138 MW, the peak load starting point for the forecasts is 
363 MW. In the basic forecast, the peak load is assumed to increase to 911 MW in 2020. This 
gives an average annual growth rate of 5.2%. The growth rate for the peak load is somewhat 
lower than the growth rate for energy demand since the load factor is assumed to increase 
during the forecast period. In the high forecast the peak load is assumed to increase to 1,316 
MW in 2020. This gives an average annual growth rate of 7.4%. 
 
C.  Supply Options 
1.  Business as Usual 
5.  Business  as  usual  assumes  that  the  existing  practices  of  energy  development  will 
continue without any changes in strategy. Development of known hydropower, natural gas, oil,

and coal reserves will continue; indigenous hydropower, natural gas, and coal will be used for 
power generation; no program on energy conservation will be initiated; and development and 
management  of  biomass  fuels  will  continue  without  any  linkages  with  commercial  energy 
development program. The gap between projected demand and indigenous supply can only be 
reduced with serious exploration program; else the gap will have to be met from imported

2.  Reference Option 
6.  Additional  issues  included  in  reference  option  are  (i)  enhancement  of  exploration,

effective programs to conserve energy; and (iii) integration of commercial energy and biomass 
fuels program to maintain sustainable supply of biomass fuels. Exploration and appraisal of oil 
and  natural  gas  will  be  enhanced;  development  of  hydropower,  natural  gas,  and  coal  will 
continue; new and renewable energy sources will be harnessed; a program will be undertaken 
to conserve commercial energy and biomass fuels; and development of biomass fuels will be 
considered along with the development of commercial energy sources. 
 
7.  A business-as-usual scenario would put a strain on the economy with a sharp increase

A.  Background 
 
1.  Afghanistan has made significant progress since the ouster of the Taliban regime. The 
Government has implemented a wide range of structural reforms and adhered to almost all 
quantitative indicators and structural benchmarks under the Staff-Monitored Program, led by the 
International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF).  Notwithstanding  these  achievements  and  double-digit 
economic growth over the last 2 years, the country is economically and fiscally fragile. Security,

external development finance that does not fiscally burden the nascent administration.  
 
1.  Debt Sustainability 
 
2.  At  the  Berlin  Donor  Conference  in  March  2004,  the  Government  presented  its 
development strategy—Securing Afghanistan's Future: Accomplishments and the Strategic Path

FINANCIAL PERFORMANCE, PROJECTIONS AND MANAGEMENT 
 
A.  Financial Position 
 
1.  Profitability. The financial accounts of the Afghanistan Electricity Authority (DABM) 
before 2001 were destroyed during the war, and only the last 2 years’ profit-and-loss accounts 
are available. Adjustments are needed because assets and depreciation costs have not been 
captured correctly. After preliminary adjustments,1 the revised DABM loss as of 20 March 2004 
would amount to AF1,300 million (about $30 million)—more than 10 times the reported loss of 
AF63.8  million  (about  $1.4  million).  This  discrepancy  results  from  depreciation  based  on 
valuation of assets and bad-debt provisions. Current low depreciation will inflate taxable income 
when the cash flow is positive. A proper asset register is urgently required to know DABM’s 
financial position. 
 
2.  DABM’s financial position has improved marginally despite revision of tariff rates by 
more than 100% in March 2003. Revenues increased by 88% but most profit has been wiped 
out by the operation of costly Kabul northwest gas turbine power plant. The fuel cost alone is 12 
cents/kWh,  which  is  much  higher  than  DABM’s  average  tariff  of  3.5  cents/kWh.  High 
transmission and distribution losses of 35–40% have increased generation and power purchase 
costs, and shortage of power has further reduced revenue. The overall cost recovery as of 20 
March 2004 is estimated at only 51%, with overall average tariff of 3.5 cents/kWh and average 
cost of supply of 7.0 cents/kWh.  
3.  Tariff. DABM has a location-specific tariff, with no uniform national tariff. These tariff 
rates vary widely depending on the source of power. Hydro-based Kabul and Kandahar have an 
average domestic tariff of around 2 cents/kWh, while Mazar-e-Sharif and Herat, which rely on 
imported  energy  and  diesel  generation,  have  tariffs  more  than  twice  and  four  times, 
respectively.  Tariffs  have  three  customer  categories:  domestic,  governmental,  and  other,2 
allowing cross-subsidization for domestic customers. In Kabul, domestic tariffs are divided into 
three brackets depending on consumption, but most domestic customers are in the lowest 
consumption bracket of below 600 kWh per 2 months. 
4.  Cash Flow. DABM manages cash shortage resulting from spare parts and fuel costs of 
Kabul northwest gas turbine power plant funded by the World Bank and United States Agency 
for International Development (USAID). Investment funds have been heavily dependent on 
Government support through donor communities. Until FY2003, even salaries of DABM staff 
were paid from the MEW budget. The cash collection rate is about only 60–70%. Billing and 
collection are based either on customers’ own readings or on bimonthly meter readings by a 
limited number of meter readers. The German Development Cooperation through GTZ and 
USAID have supported pilot programs to improve billing and collection efficiency of DABM.

B.  Financial Performance Improvement 
 
5.  Four key drivers would quickly improve DABM’s financial performance: expansion of 
capacity to meet increasing demand; efficiency improvement in generation, transmission, and 
distribution; improvement of billing and collection system; and tariff increase to improve cost 
recovery.  
6.  Capacity. Alternative, cheaper power must be generated or imported, and transmission 
and distribution capacity must be expanded and rehabilitated to meet demand. Rehabilitation of 
hydro power plants is expected to increase capacity but will not be enough to meet growing 
demand for electricity. Full operation of the trunk transmission line from Termez via Pul-e-
Khumri to Kabul is expected to enable MEW and DABM to import power from neighboring 
countries to meet demand in the northern and eastern regions. 
7.  Efficiency. The operational efficiency of the generation, transmission, and distribution 
network needs to be improved immediately. High losses, suboptimal dispatch, and expensive 
diesel generation are the key contributors to the high cost of supply. 
8.  Billing and Collection. DABM’s uncollected revenues (around AF1,300 million or $30 
million as of the end of October 2004) are mostly owed by Government sector customers (e.g., 
ministries,  jails,  the  military,  police,  etc).  To  enable  DABM  to  recover  its  arrears3  and 
consistently collect the billed amounts, the  Government will make a budget appropriation to 
ensure timely payment so that, from 20 March 2007 onward, DABM can maintain accounts 
receivable from all customers equivalent to less than the preceding 3 months’ of sales. The 
Government will issue a policy against theft and on disconnection, and DABM will be vigilant in 
order to minimize nontechnical losses. 
9.  Cost Recovery.  The rationalization of tariff to meet full cost recovery must consider 
social impacts on customers who consume the least (55% of total consumers in Kabul), adverse 
environmental impacts of using alternative energy with pollution risks, and operational and 
financial sustainability of DABM. Ongoing and future rehabilitation and reconstruction of hydro 
plants and the increase of inexpensive power imports are expected to gradually improve the 
cost recovery of DABM, and that the transmission line from Uzbekistan to Kabul can largely 
release suppressed demand around the northern and eastern regions and cause a financial 
turnaround. However, an indicative financial projection of DABM (Table A10) suggests that 
DABM should increase Kabul-based tariff4 by 10% annually for the next 3 to 4 years so that 
DABM can maintain full cost recovery after the turnaround, retain enough free cash flow to carry

2.  In the north, the transmission line routes traverse the fertile floodplains of the Kunduz and 
Amudaryu rivers (<300 meters [m] elevation) and their adjacent hinterland comprising a rolling, loess-
covered piedmont plain (300–400 m elevation). In the central eastern area, the routes traverse alpine 
areas  comprising  deeply  dissected  mountains  (1,800–4,700  m  above  sea  level  [asl])  and

3..  The  northern  area  consists  mainly  of  quaternary  conglomerates,  sand,  and  loess,  with 
scattered inliers of tertiary limestone overlain by thick (5–20 m) and generally fertile, sandy soils. The 
central eastern region comprises tertiary sedimentary rocks and volcanic overlying Mesozoic and

4.  The project areas have a dry continental climate, with four distinct seasons and wide annual

flows of Amudaryu and Kunduz rivers. The Kabul River and its tributaries drain the central eastern 
region, with their flows derived entirely from rainfall and seasonal snow melt of the surrounding 
mountains. Surface water is limited, with peak flows in spring, and sporadic or nonexistent flows in 
many watercourses in summer.

POVERTY AND SOCIAL ANALYSIS 
 
 
1.  A survey of about 1,100 households estimated that 2.88 million people are living in 
poverty (using the $1-a-day benchmark). The sample was 42% urban (i.e., living in, or within 10 
km of, a town or city) and 58% rural. Average daily per capita income across the sample was 39 
cents per day (the same for male-headed households). Female-headed households (only 1% of 
the sample) earned per capita 48 cents per day (although the average household income is 
20% lower for female-headed households, the survey also revealed that family size is two thirds 
that of male-headed households, resulting in higher per capita income). Only 10% of the sample 
earns more than $1 per day per capita. 
 
2.  The average household size is 12.8 for male-headed households and 8.4 for female-
headed households. The high average household size is in part due to a high fertility rate of 6.8, 
but  also  to  a  nonnuclear  family  structure,  with  one  household  often  comprising  three 
generations, more than one wife per married male, and married brothers and their families living 
together under the same roof.  The survey reveals that approximately 31% of female-headed 
households are concentrated in the lowest income quintile, with more male-headed households 
proportionate to female-headed households in the upper quintiles.  A large proportion (85.7%) of 
the population reported owning their own homes, with only 8.5% renting their homes and 4.6% 
living in their homes for free. Most dwellings are made of mud brick (95%).  
 
3.  The survey concludes that populations in all project areas are growing, the situations of 
most households are improving, and there is a healthy demand for electricity as well as the 
lighting and electrical appliances, all of which spells a significant increase in demand. Improved 
electricity services could impact positively on the home-based business sector. No households 
enjoy a 24-hour supply. The average is 15 hours per day across the five grid-connected towns 
(which is why alternate forms of energy, particularly kerosene for lighting, are used pervasively). 
The  average  is  far  lower  if  towns  using  a  community  or  village  generator  are  included. 
Residents in all towns desire supply 24-hours a day, and are willing to pay a connection fee to 
have it. 
 
4.  Households using grid electricity, and those that do not are fairly evenly distributed 
across the income quintiles. Use of grid electricity is therefore not so much determined by 
income but by location: if electricity is available, it will be used, regardless of the users’ income 
level. We can determine from patterns of expenditure on forms of energy that can be replaced 
by grid electricity that the poorest income quintile will not only be able to afford it but will also 
increase their energy consumption without spending more. Each town has different income and 
expenditure characteristics and electricity consumption. Pricing mechanisms for power will need 
to take these differences into consideration.

1.  The Government has initiated an innovative incentive based mechanism, the Priority 
Reform  and  Restructuring  (PRR)  program,  to  fast-track  reform  in  the  public  sector  of 
Afghanistan, and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been supporting the PRR process 
through the ongoing technical assistance (TA) cluster.1 The effective operation of the power 
sector hinges on immediate capacity building in (i) commercialization activities, (ii) billing and 
collection, (iii) accounting systems, (iv) cost of service analysis, (v) operative metering and 
connections, (vi) theft control, and (vii) new connection. Sustainability of reform will be ensured 
through a comprehensive capacity building initiative. As the World Bank, German Development 
Cooperation (GTZ), and United States Agency for International Development (USAID) are 
actively focusing on the first two areas—commercialization, and billing and collection—ADB will

2.  The objective of the TA is to improve effective operation of the power sector by providing 
technical and accounting training. Three streams of training packages will be developed: 
 
(i)  business  management:  general  business  management,  portfolio  review,  and 
program management;  
 
(ii)  technical  operation:  technical  operation  of  generation,  transmission,  and 
distribution in the power sector; power plant protection; metering (meter readers, 
meter  installation,  and  disconnection);  loss  management;  and  optimum 
dispatching; and 
 
(iii)  accounting  and  economic  management:  accounting  (e.g.,  double-entry 
bookkeeping, register, accrual-basis accounting); contracting; procurement and 
inventory management; financial reporting; management information system; and 
economics of cost recovery and tariff setting. 
 
3.  The TA will help improve skills that will increase the overall efficiency of operations. It will 
improve customer service delivery and overall  safety standards, and daily operations and 
technical and financial record keeping. 
 
4.  It  is  essential  that  the  training  packages  are  implemented  using  existing  training 
resources within the Ministry. Therefore there is a requirement to upskill the trainers within the 
Department of Education-Ministry of Education and Water who number approximately 60, and

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS  
 
A.  Rationale 
   
1.  Government is the main investor in electricity transmission all over the world. Investment 
in power transmission involves large amounts of capital, little maintenance cost, and a return 
over a long period. Government or an independent regulator regulates this sector because of its 
natural monopoly characteristics; high fixed costs making it unprofitable for a second firm to 
enter and compete.  
 
2.  All the components are part of the least-cost expansion program developed under the 
power system master plan. The plan considers supply alternatives to areas without grid supply 
and  with  large-scale  isolated  diesel  generation.  The  Project  is  the  least-cost  option  for 
developing transmission and distribution network in the selected cities. On an incremental basis, 
the Project will greatly reduce reliance on inefficient and high-cost village, household, and 
enterprise self-generation at unit costs in the range $0.15–0.55/kWh, replaced with an estimated 
average incremental cost of grid-connected electricity of $0.079/kWh. 
 
B.  Economic Cost of Project Components 
 
3.  To convert financial project cost into economic cost, turnover and income taxes were 
deducted, and connection costs added (after allowing for the about 18,000 electrification kits 
that will be distributed to the poorest households as part of the Project). Annual operation and 
maintenance and administration costs were calculated in economic prices (financial prices 
adjusted using the standard conversion factor). No price contingencies are included in the base 
capital  cost  but  the  economic  capital  costs  include  physical  contingencies.  Costs  were 
separated into foreign exchange and local costs. A standard conversion factor of 0.9 was used. 
The  cost  of  supply  was  valued  based  on  the  long-run  marginal  cost  for  generation  and 
transmission as calculated in the power sector master plan. 
 
4.  Consistent with the financial analysis, 30 years is used for the project economic analysis. 
Investment is assumed to take place during 2005–2007, and projects benefits are assumed to 
be realized from 2007. Beyond 2020, further investment will be required to meet incremental 
demand growth. 
 
C.  Quantification of Benefits 
 
5.  The main benefits are from (i) eventual connection to northern neighboring countries for 
the long-term reliable electricity; (ii) connection of new customers to electricity; (iii) improved 
availability  and  reliability;  and  (iv)  supply  of  electricity  from  non-diesel  sources  and  loss 
reduction. The incremental and non-incremental benefits were selected separately. Incremental 
benefit was calculated using customers’ willingness to pay, and the non-incremental benefit was 
not captured in the calculation, as resource cost savings for individual components could not be 
reliably estimated. 
 
6.  The reductions in technical and nontechnical losses were derived from the power system 
master plan forecast, and were applied uniformly across all components. In general, technical 
losses at the distribution level are assumed to reduce from present levels of approximately 19% 
of energy sales to 12% by 2020. Nontechnical losses are assumed to reduce from present 
levels to 6% over the same period. Loss reduction has been applied to incremental and non-
incremental sales in calculating benefit streams.

Appendix 15  55 
 
7.  Most households in the project area have no access to grid electricity. However, village-
sponsored  systems  and  privately  operated  generators  based  on  diesel  or  petrol-powered 
gensets provide limited amounts of electricity. Thus, even in the absence of grid supply, the 
residential, Government, and “other” sectors consume a certain amount of electricity, although 
the price paid is substantially higher than the grid-connected customers. 
 
1.  Domestic Consumers 
 
8.  For  economic  analysis,  adjustments  were  made  to  incremental  electricity  sales,  to 
exclude  non-incremental  energy  consumption  (existing  energy  consumption  that  will  be 
captured by Afghanistan Electricity Authority [DABM] as the network is rehabilitated). Based on 
findings  of  the  socioeconomic  survey,  domestic  average  non-incremental  demand  was 
estimated at 9.3 kWh per month per household. For other consumer groups, it was assumed 
that estimated suppressed demand is met from other electrical and nonelectrical sources. 
 
9.  The economic benefits of extending grid supply to unserved areas are estimated based 
on the cost of alternative energy sources used for existing consumption levels, and based on 
the willingness to pay for induced consumption as a consequence of the availability of reliable 
grid  supply.  Analysis  of  the  socioeconomic  survey  revealed  that  the  non-incremental 
consumption of electricity or its equivalent in other forms of energy is approximately AF270 
($5.80) per household per month, whether grid-connected or not. Households that have access 
to  electricity  include  many  that  are  supplied  by  village-operated  petrol-  or  diesel-powered 
gensets, for an average of about 5 hours per day. The average expenditure per household from 
this source is AF236 ($5.12) per month for consumption of 9.3 kWh, equivalent to AF25.3/kWh 
($0.55/kWh).  
 
10.  Households in project areas connected to the grid and paying a tariff of AF0.96–2.5/kWh 
($0.02–0.05/kWh), spend on average AF270 ($5.86) per month for electricity, consuming 107–
281 kWh per household per month. Incremental consumption of electricity within the project 
areas in the domestic sector is thus 98.5–280 kWh per month per household (total average 
consumption with the project less non-incremental consumption). Non-incremental consumption 
of electricity is thus valued at the resource cost of AF25.3/kWh ($0.55/kWh). 
 
11.  Incremental consumption of electricity, valued assuming a linear demand function (that 
is, assuming that 50% of the difference between the current tariff and the cost of the alternative 
represents consumer surplus), is estimated at AF13.9 /kWh (3.23 c/kWh). A semi-log demand 
function, which would theoretically lower the value of the incremental consumption, was not 
used, as the price change would not be significant after rounding to one decimal place in US 
dollars. 
 
12.  The analysis ignored the benefit from supply reliability improvements as the level of 
industrialization is very low in Afghanistan and, consequently, the difference between the value 
of lost load and tariff will be low. An average incremental cost of future electricity supply (to the 
medium voltage bus bar) was estimated as part of the power system master plan to be 
approximately AF3.6 /kWh (9 c/kWh) for the integrated central grid. Most customers in the 
current and expanded network will be connected at the low-voltage level. At current tariffs then, 
supply costs are typically under-recovered, and a prima facie economic subsidy to domestic 
consumers will be realized as the system expands.

56  Appendix 15 
D.  Economic Model and Evaluation 
13.  To test the economic viability of each of the components, the economic internal rate of 
return (EIRR) was calculated on the basis of incremental cost-and-benefit streams associated 
with each project. The economic analysis evaluated the economic performance of the proposed 
components by comparing the with- and without-project scenarios, i.e., the economic value of 
the incremental and non-incremental supply of electricity that the components will provide 
compared with the existing patterns of energy use in non-electrified areas. 
 
14.  Economic returns are acceptable for all projects and robust for most. This stems from 
grid extensions’ capacity to bring urban-quality power at the urban tariff to rural villages that 
would otherwise face high costs for low-quality service. On average, the Project will allow poor 
households to consume 10 times the electricity than they had access to under a similar 
household budget without the Project.

Appendix 16  57 
FINANCIAL ANALYSIS  
A.  Project Cost 
 
1.  The  total  project  cost  includes  physical  and  price  contingencies,  interest  during 
construction, and provisions for security and de-mining. Physical contingency is provisioned on 
8% of the project base cost. The project cost, including physical contingency, is based on 
constant 2005 prices. Allowance for price contingency provides for future price escalation due to 
fluctuation of foreign and domestic inflation.1 Interest charge of 1% per annum during the grace 
period will be capitalized and charged to the loan account. The total project cost also includes 
provisions  for  support  facilities,  de-mining  and  security  activities,  resettlement  and  its 
monitoring, and consulting services, which will all support project implementation. Local taxes 
and duties are not payable under the Project. 
 
B.  Project Financial and Economic Evaluation 
 
1.  Financial Analysis 
 
2.  Methodology. Subproject components were planned cost-effectively. Since the financial 
impacts of the transmission and distribution components are interdependent, they have been 
combined for financial evaluation. A period of 30 years has been used for the project evaluation. 
Investment is expected to take place during 2005–2007 and project benefits will be realized 
from 2007. Beyond 2020, further investment will be required to meet incremental demand 
growth. All benefit-and-cost streams are determined in constant 2005 dollar terms.  
 
3.  Financial Benefits. From a financial perspective, project benefits will be generated from 
incremental  sales  resulting  from  reduction  of  transmission  and  distribution  losses.  The 
rehabilitation  and  construction  of  transmission  and  distribution  systems  will  enable  older 
systems to be gradually retired as appropriate, thereby reducing losses and increasing reliability 
and quality of supply. Under the current situation of acute power supply shortfall against 
demand in the areas, additional project benefits will also depend on release of the present 
suppressed demand and ability to meet growing demand. Distribution loss is will be gradually 
reduced by 0.6% on an annual average for next 3 years during project implementation2 while 
transmission loss accruing from new transmission components is taken on 1.5%.    
 
4.  Financial  Costs.  For  the  purpose  of  financial  evaluation,  cost  streams  reflect 
incremental costs in delivering the benefits identified. The financial costs comprise capital, 
incremental energy, operation and maintenance (O&M), administration, particularly additional 
billing, costs, and taxation. The capital costs include physical contingencies. Incremental energy 
costs are accrued to additional generation and power purchase to be supplied to the project 
area. O&M costs for transmission and distribution systems are assumed on 1.0% and 1.5% of 
required  capital  costs.  The  size  of  incremental  administration  costs,  including  billing  and 
collection costs, is minor but is assumed to increase in proportion to consumption growth since 
distribution projects contribute to a large number of new connections (para 1). Project cash 
flows will be taxed in accordance with the existing tax regime for state enterprises—2% tax on 
turnover (electricity sales) and 20% tax on net income.
